channel.title: Weight loss and muscle growth
channel.description:
Uni and holiday is coming up soon, so I'm aiming to lose as much weight as I can within 3 months. I have been working out a lot lately, and doing very little cardio so I want to switch this but I am not sure of the type of routine I should be doing/what foods I should be eating etc.
I'm 6ft tall, about 180 lbs with a big build. Ideally I'd want to be more toned than thin looking.
I am a member of a gym, with their main cardio machines being treadmills, crosstrainers, rowers, cycles, steps. I'm up for going about 5 times a week, but just dont know what sort of routine I shoud follow.
Tips/advice please :)

item.title: Weight loss and muscle growth
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

hmm, ok, so here’s my new lifestyle…

Monday - Arms (inc Shoulders), Chest and Back - Doing 4 sets of 12 rep squats
Tuesday - 10 minute walk followed by a half hour jog followed by a half hour cycle
Wednesday - Legs, abdominals and arms - Along with the squats
Thursday - Cross trainer for 40 minutes, followed by a 25 minute row
Friday - Chest, legs and back - with squats
Sat - Rest
Sun - Rest

Is this sort of weekly routine too much or is it ok? Each weight session I basically do most of the compound lifts and then focus on specific muscles doing around 4-5 sets on each.

My diet mainly consists of:
Breakfast - Oats with milk and a banana
Snack - Some sort of fruit
Lunch - Brown rice with 2 poached eggs
GYM SESSION
Snack - Tuna sandwich, turkey sandwich, Oats with banana, some other protein rich foodage
Dinner - Meat with new potatoes and vedgetables
Snack - some sort of fruit again

Any suggestions?

item.title: Weight loss and muscle growth
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Most people don’t actually do HIIT properly; they think they are, but at the end of the day they aren’t really putting in.
Jogging isn’t that bad. Neither is something like cycling at a steady pace, for that matter.

Weight training is definitely the most important part though, and should come first. You absolutely need to be doing squats.
I started out doing the Stronglifts 5x5 program for beginners, but found that the rest time that was being used was too drawn out for my liking.
I changed over to the 20 squats program (ie, one set with 20 squats in it); it fucks you up. You get to the 5th rep and you’re thinking “yeah, pretty easy – no dramas”. 5 reps later you’re starting to breathe heavy because of elevated heartrate. Once you hit rep 15, the final 5 reps can be a nightmare. Even though it’s only one set, you will definitely experience strength gains.
After I do the squats, I then move to dips, chinsups/pullups, and pushups.

As for eating, you said you want to slim down. What I would do is convert your weight to pounds, multiply that by 16kCal, and then eat that amount minus 100 - 200 kCal to begin with. You want to reduce intake steadily so that your body isn’t shocked into a starvation response accidentally. Make sure you eat starchy carbs pre and post workout only.
The downside with this is that muscular growth won’t happen (strength gains will though), and you might even feel a bit fatigued during workouts.
You want to be eating at least 1 gram of protein per pound of bodyweight, too. There’s 4 kCal per gram of protein, 4kCal per gram of carbohydrates, and 9kCal per gram of fat.

Personally, I think the macronutrient ratio (Protein:Carbohydrates:Fat) 30:50:20 is a good starting point. Since you’re cutting, you might want to experience with carb cycling. Do a high carb day (30:50:20) and then a low carb day or two (45:30:25). On the law carb day, you might also want to lower the number of calories that you take in.
The reality is that counting calories is completely unnecessary for fat loss, but if you want more bang for your buck then the clinical approach will deliver.

item.title: Weight loss and muscle growth
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

Cardio isn’t a great way to lose weight unless you do HIIT. 10*200m with 2 mins recovery is a pretty intense session, do them at 30-37 seconds each depending on how fit you are but keep it consistent.

Doing weights and building muscle raises your base metabolic rate, which makes it easier to cut fat.

Get plenty of protein in so eggs, chicken, fish, nuts etc Eat whatever else as long as it’s healthy. Low in sugar and fat, and as least processed as possible.
